title: How to Sew an Insulated Lunch Box

steps.headline: Obtain the items listed below in the "Things You Will Need" section.
Launder all fabrics to remove sizing, starches, etc.
Iron the fabrics smooth if necessary.
Measure and mark your basic pattern on paper.
steps.description: You'll need an old newspaper sheet or craft paper for this.

steps.headline: *Note that the measurements allow a quarter inch (1/2 cm) seam allowance on all pieces.
steps.description: (see pic for help)  Begin with a 10.5 x 20.5 inch rectangle.

steps.headline: Add a 6 x 6 flap to the top edge as shown.
steps.description: Note, this flap shape can be modified to nearly any shape. The author has modified it to a rounded shape to simulate the face/head of a pig. (See tips)

steps.headline: Add a 4.5 x 6.5 flap to the bottom edge as shown.
Cut four of this main pattern.
steps.description: One from outer shell fabric, one from inner shell fabric, one from insulation and one from interfacing.

steps.headline: Mark the long edges of the rectangle with pins to mark your bag's "corner edges".
Iron the interfacing to your outside fabric to stiffen it.
Sew the short sides of your rectangles together.
steps.description: First the outer layer, then the inner layer, then your insulation.

steps.headline: Assemble and pin all three layers together with their top flap edges together.
steps.description: Inner and outer layer should be facing, insulation can be on the back of either layer.

steps.headline: Sew along the opening edge.
Clip insulation back to the seam line.
Clip all corners to ease turning.
Pin and sew the OUTER fabric bottom rectangle to itself to form the bottom.
Turn the bag right side out.
Pin the top edge and then top stitch it to hold it in place.
steps.description: You can add "quilting" stitches to the bag at this point to help hold the layers together if you wish.

steps.headline: Add your cardboard or plastic stiffening to the inside bottom of the bag.
Hand tack the stiffening to the bottom.
Hand sew the liner bottom to the liner sides, taking care to turn raw edges under.
steps.description: You "can" turn the bag back "inside out" for this process to give you better access to the seam you are sewing.

steps.headline: Fold over top closure flap and mark the placement of your Velcro closure.
Mark handle positions.
steps.description: Pin ends of webbing in place. Machine sew them to the bag. You can do this as a single loop from one narrow side of the bag to the other, or you can do this as a double D handle, sewing one D to the back of the bag and one D to the front of the bag under the flap.

steps.headline: Customize - Will add ideas here later.

tyn: yard (0.46 m) of cotton quilting fabric for the outside
yard (0.46 m) of cotton quilting fabric for the inside
yard (0.46 m) of insulation fleece fabric
text: Obtain the items listed below in the "Things You Will Need" section.  Launder all fabrics to remove sizing, starches, etc.  Iron the fabrics smooth if necessary.  Measure and mark your basic pattern on paper. You'll need an old newspaper sheet or craft paper for this. *Note that the measurements allow a quarter inch (1/2 cm) seam allowance on all pieces. (see pic for help)  Begin with a 10.5 x 20.5 inch rectangle. Add a 6 x 6 flap to the top edge as shown. Note, this flap shape can be modified to nearly any shape. The author has modified it to a rounded shape to simulate the face/head of a pig. (See tips) Add a 4.5 x 6.5 flap to the bottom edge as shown.  Cut four of this main pattern. One from outer shell fabric, one from inner shell fabric, one from insulation and one from interfacing. Mark the long edges of the rectangle with pins to mark your bag's "corner edges".  Iron the interfacing to your outside fabric to stiffen it.  Sew the short sides of your rectangles together. First the outer layer, then the inner layer, then your insulation. Assemble and pin all three layers together with their top flap edges together. Inner and outer layer should be facing, insulation can be on the back of either layer. Sew along the opening edge.  Clip insulation back to the seam line.  Clip all corners to ease turning.  Pin and sew the OUTER fabric bottom rectangle to itself to form the bottom.  Turn the bag right side out.  Pin the top edge and then top stitch it to hold it in place. You can add "quilting" stitches to the bag at this point to help hold the layers together if you wish. Add your cardboard or plastic stiffening to the inside bottom of the bag.  Hand tack the stiffening to the bottom.  Hand sew the liner bottom to the liner sides, taking care to turn raw edges under. You "can" turn the bag back "inside out" for this process to give you better access to the seam you are sewing. Fold over top closure flap and mark the placement of your Velcro closure. Sew it in place. Mark handle positions. Pin ends of webbing in place. Machine sew them to the bag. You can do this as a single loop from one narrow side of the bag to the other, or you can do this as a double D handle, sewing one D to the back of the bag and one D to the front of the bag under the flap. Customize - Will add ideas here later.
sentences: Obtain the items listed below in the "Things You Will Need" section.
Launder all fabrics to remove sizing, starches, etc.
Iron the fabrics smooth if necessary.
Measure and mark your basic pattern on paper.
You'll need an old newspaper sheet or craft paper for this.
*Note that the measurements allow a quarter inch (1/2 cm) seam allowance on all pieces.
(see pic for help)  Begin with a 10.5 x 20.5 inch rectangle.
Add a 6 x 6 flap to the top edge as shown.
Note, this flap shape can be modified to nearly any shape.
The author has modified it to a rounded shape to simulate the face/head of a pig.
(See tips) Add a 4.5 x 6.5 flap to the bottom edge as shown.
Cut four of this main pattern.
One from outer shell fabric, one from inner shell fabric, one from insulation and one from interfacing.
Mark the long edges of the rectangle with pins to mark your bag's "corner edges".
Iron the interfacing to your outside fabric to stiffen it.
Sew the short sides of your rectangles together.
First the outer layer, then the inner layer, then your insulation.
Assemble and pin all three layers together with their top flap edges together.
Inner and outer layer should be facing, insulation can be on the back of either layer.
Sew along the opening edge.
Clip insulation back to the seam line.
Clip all corners to ease turning.
Pin and sew the OUTER fabric bottom rectangle to itself to form the bottom.
Turn the bag right side out.
Pin the top edge and then top stitch it to hold it in place.
You can add "quilting" stitches to the bag at this point to help hold the layers together if you wish.
Add your cardboard or plastic stiffening to the inside bottom of the bag.
Hand tack the stiffening to the bottom.
Hand sew the liner bottom to the liner sides, taking care to turn raw edges under.
You "can" turn the bag back "inside out" for this process to give you better access to the seam you are sewing.
Fold over top closure flap and mark the placement of your Velcro closure.
Sew it in place.
Mark handle positions.
Pin ends of webbing in place.
Machine sew them to the bag.

You can do this as a single loop from one narrow side of the bag to the other, or you can do this as a double D handle, sewing one D to the back of the bag and one D to the front of the bag under the flap.
Customize - Will add ideas here later.
